title: General Wave Properties: Definitions, Calculations, and Applications
subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a transverse wave?
options: A wave that transfers energy without transferring matter
A wave where the particles vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation
A wave that requires a medium to travel through
A wave where the particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation
questions.explanation: In transverse waves, particle displacement is perpendicular to wave direction. Examples include light waves and waves on a string.

questions.question: What is the definition of wavelength?
options: Time taken for one complete wave to pass a point
Maximum displacement from the rest position
Distance between two consecutive points in phase on a wave
Number of complete waves passing a point per second
questions.explanation: Wavelength (λ) is measured between two consecutive crests, troughs, or any two points that are in phase.

questions.question: If a wave has a frequency of 50 Hz and a wavelength of 0.5 m, what is its wave speed?
questions.explanation: Wave speed v = f × λ = 50 Hz × 0.5 m = 25 m/s. This relationship applies to all types of waves.

questions.question: What is the period of a wave with frequency 20 Hz?
questions.explanation: Period T = 1/f = 1/20 = 0.05 s. Period is the time for one complete oscillation.

questions.question: Which type of wave can travel through a vacuum?
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic waves (e.g., light, radio) can travel through a vacuum; mechanical waves require a medium to propagate.

questions.question: A marker on a rope moves up and down 12 times in 4 seconds as a wave passes. What is the frequency of the wave?
questions.explanation: Frequency = number of oscillations ÷ time = 12 ÷ 4 = 3 Hz. This measures how many complete waves pass a point each second.

questions.question: What is the amplitude of a wave?
options: Maximum displacement from the rest position
questions.explanation: Amplitude is the maximum displacement from equilibrium. It determines the energy carried by the wave.

questions.question: A wave on a string travels at 40 m/s with a wavelength of 0.8 m. What is its frequency?
questions.explanation: f = v/λ = 40 m/s ÷ 0.8 m = 50 Hz. This calculation works for any wave where speed, frequency and wavelength are related.

questions.question: Which wave property is directly related to the energy carried by the wave?
questions.explanation: Energy carried by a wave is proportional to the square of its amplitude. Larger amplitude means more energy, regardless of wave type.

questions.question: What happens to wavelength if frequency doubles and wave speed remains constant?
questions.explanation: From v = fλ, if v is constant and f doubles, λ must halve to keep the product unchanged.

questions.question: Which diagram shows correct labeling of amplitude and wavelength on a transverse wave?
options: Amplitude: distance from trough to crest; Wavelength: distance from crest to trough
Amplitude: horizontal arrow from crest to crest; Wavelength: vertical arrow from rest position to crest
Amplitude: vertical arrow from rest position to crest; Wavelength: horizontal arrow from crest to crest
Amplitude and wavelength are both measured horizontally
questions.explanation: Amplitude is measured vertically from rest position to crest (or trough). Wavelength is measured horizontally between two consecutive identical points.

questions.question: A wave travels 90 m in 3 seconds. If its frequency is 15 Hz, what is its wavelength?
questions.explanation: First find speed: v = distance/time = 90 m ÷ 3 s = 30 m/s. Then λ = v/f = 30 m/s ÷ 15 Hz = 2 m.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a longitudinal wave?
options: A wave with compressions and rarefactions that cannot transfer energy
A wave where the particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation
A wave that can only travel through solids
A wave where the particles vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation
questions.explanation: In longitudinal waves, particle displacement is parallel to wave direction. Examples include sound waves in air and seismic P-waves.

questions.question: If a wave's period is 0.25 s, how many complete waves pass a fixed point in 10 seconds?
questions.explanation: Number of waves = total time ÷ period = 10 s ÷ 0.25 s = 40 waves.

questions.question: Which application primarily uses the reflection of electromagnetic waves?
questions.explanation: Radar uses reflection of radio waves (electromagnetic waves) to detect objects. Echo sounding and ultrasound use sound waves; seismic surveying uses mechanical waves in the ground.
